<script language="JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_swapImgRestore() { //v3.0
  var i,x,a=document.MM_sr; for(i=0;a&&i<a.length&&(x=a[i])&&x.oSrc;i++) x.src=x.oSrc;
}

function MM_preloadImages() { //v3.0
  var d=document; if(d.images){ if(!d.MM_p) d.MM_p=new Array();
    var i,j=d.MM_p.length,a=MM_preloadImages.arguments; for(i=0; i<a.length; i++)
    if (a[i].indexOf("#")!=0){ d.MM_p[j]=new Image; d.MM_p[j++].src=a[i];}}
}

function MM_findObj(n, d) { //v4.0
  var p,i,x;  if(!d) d=document; if((p=n.indexOf("?"))>0&&parent.frames.length) {
    d=parent.frames[n.substring(p+1)].document; n=n.substring(0,p);}
  if(!(x=d[n])&&d.all) x=d.all[n]; for (i=0;!x&&i<d.forms.length;i++) x=d.forms[i][n];
  for(i=0;!x&&d.layers&&i<d.layers.length;i++) x=MM_findObj(n,d.layers[i].document);
  if(!x && document.getElementById) x=document.getElementById(n); return x;
}

function MM_swapImage() { //v3.0
  var i,j=0,x,a=MM_swapImage.arguments; document.MM_sr=new Array; for(i=0;i<(a.length-2);i+=3)
   if ((x=MM_findObj(a[i]))!=null){document.MM_sr[j++]=x; if(!x.oSrc) x.oSrc=x.src; x.src=a[i+2];}
}
//-->
</script>

            			<!-- Page Title -->
                       <p align="center"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="5"><b><font color="#000099" size="6">
                       PHP Tutorial<br>
              <font size="4" color="#000000">Part 3 - IF Statements</font></font></b></font></p>

              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/1">Part 1 - Introduction</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/2">Part 2 - Displaying Information & Variables</a></li><li><b>Part 3 - IF Statements</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/4">Part 4 - Loops and Arrays</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/5">Part 5 - E-mail With PHP</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/6">Part 6 - PHP With Forms</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/7">Part 7 - Final Notes</a></li></ul></font>

              <!-- Page Content -->
              <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">
              <div align="right" style="float:right">
<iframe src="http://rcm.amazon.com/e/cm?t=freewebmaster-20&o=1&p=14&l=st1&mode=books&search=php&fc1=000000&lt1=&lc1=3366FF&bg1=FFFFFF&f=ifr" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="160" height="600" border="0" frameborder="0" style="border:none;" scrolling="no"></iframe>
</div><font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Introduction</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Over the past two parts I have shown you the basics of text in PHP and how to store it as variables. In this part of the tutorial I will show you how to use IF statements to make decisions in your scripts.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>The Basics Of IF</b></big></font><br />
<br />
If statements are used to compare two values and carry out different actions based on the results of the test. If statements take the form IF, THEN, ELSE. Basically the IF part checks for a condition. If it is true, the then statement is executed. If not, the else statement is executed.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>IF Strucure</b></big></font><br />
<br />
The structure of an IF statement is as follows:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
IF (something == something else)<br />
{<br />
THEN Statement<br />
} else {<br />
ELSE Statement<br />
}<br />
</font><br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Variables</b></big></font><br />
<br />
The most common use of an IF statement is to compare a variable to another piece of text, a number, or another variable. For example:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
if ($username == &quot;webmaster&quot;)<br />
</font><br />
which would compare the contents of the variable to the text string. The THEN section of code will only be executed if the variable is exactly the same as the contents of the quotation marks so if the variable contained &#039;Webmaster&#039; or &#039;WEBMASTER&#039; it will be false.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Constructing The THEN Statment</b></big></font><br />
<br />
To add to your script, you can now add a THEN statement:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
if ($username == &quot;webmaster&quot;) {<br />
echo &quot;Please enter your password below&quot;;<br />
}<br />
</font><br />
This will only display this text if the username is webmaster. If not, nothing will be displayed. You can actually leave an IF statement like this, as there is no actual requirement to have an ELSE part. This is especially useful if you are using multiple IF statements.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Constructing The ELSE Statement</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Adding The ELSE statement is as easy as the THEN statement. Just add some extra code:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
if ($username == &quot;webmaster&quot;) {<br />
echo &quot;Please enter your password below&quot;;<br />
} else {<br />
echo &quot;We are sorry but you are not a recognised user&quot;;<br />
}<br />
</font><br />
Of course, you are not limited to just one line of code. You can add any PHP commands in between the curly brackets. You can even include other IF statments (nested statements).<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Other Comparisons</b></big></font><br />
<br />
There are other ways you can use your IF statement to compare values. Firstly, you can compare two different variables to see if their values match e.g.<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
if ($enteredpass == $password)<br />
</font><br />
You can also use the standard comparision symbols to check to see if one variable is greater than or less than another:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
if ($age &lt; &quot;13&quot;)<br />
</font><br />
Or :<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
if ($date &gt; $finished)<br />
</font><br />
You can also check for multiple tests in one IF statement. For instance, if you have a form and you want to check if any of the fields were left blank you could use:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
if ($name == &quot;&quot; || $email == &quot;&quot; || $password == &quot;&quot;) {<br />
echo &quot;Please fill in all the fields&quot;;<br />
}<br />
</font><br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Part 4</b></big></font><br />
<br />
In part four I will show you some other ways of using your PHP script to do other types of checks and loops.</font></p>

              <!-- Bottom Navigation -->
              <table width="100%" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2" border="0">
              <tr>
              
              
              
              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/1">Part 1 - Introduction</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/2">Part 2 - Displaying Information & Variables</a></li><li><b>Part 3 - IF Statements</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/4">Part 4 - Loops and Arrays</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/5">Part 5 - E-mail With PHP</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/6">Part 6 - PHP With Forms</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/php/7">Part 7 - Final Notes</a></li></ul></font></p></td>
              
              <!-- Related Links -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top">

</ul></font>
</td>

     data-ad-slot="9522128591"></ins>
